summary: The Freud lens reveals the host journey as a graduated negotiation between instinctual freedom (the host's desire to control their private space) and civilizational participation (the marketplace's demand that they share it with vetted strangers). Every phase requires a new act of renunciation that the platform must make psychologically viable through proportional value delivery. The seven UI elements synthesize this insight across all layers: a value-first discovery earnings card that protects pre-civilizational curiosity, a listing wizard with dignified progress preservation, an urgency-first host dashboard structured as civilizational order, a proposal review card that resolves stranger-threat anxiety through trust-before-terms architecture, a bidirectional protection dialog that makes platform constraints feel like mutual safety, a stay cycle ritual card that contains active-lease anxiety through predictable repetition, and a cumulative hosting summary that counteracts the narcissism of minor differences at retention. Together they form a coherent system where every instinctual sacrifice is compensated, every constraint is bidirectional, and every ritual confirms the civilizational contract is holding.

elements.name: Discovery Earnings Estimator Card
elements.description: A self-contained earnings card shown to prospective hosts before any registration or sign-up is required. It surfaces local market demand, average host earnings, and guest search volume -- all without asking the host for a single piece of information. Freud's insight that premature civilizational demands trigger instinctual revolt ('we should be much happier if we were to give it up') informs the zero-ask design: the host sees value before the platform asks for anything. The card implements the L1 graduated renunciation principle (value precedes every disclosure), the L2 progressive disclosure architecture (platform gives before it takes), the L3 warm containment pattern, the L4 protective error handling, and the L5 pre-civilizational curiosity emotion (generous demonstration without threshold crossing).

visual_spec.layout: Single card, max-width 480px, centered. Top section: headline earnings figure. Middle section: three supporting metrics in a horizontal row. Bottom section: soft CTA text link, no button.

color_usage.earnings_figure: var(--primary-purple, #31135D) -- brand authority for the headline number
color_usage.metric_icons: var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109, 49, 194)) -- interactive-level purple for visual anchors
color_usage.background_tint: var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252, 250, 255)) -- warm purple tint signals safety before content is read

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Content fades in with a 400ms ease-out upward drift. Earnings figure appears first (staggered 100ms before supporting metrics). No loading spinner -- the card renders with cached or geo-estimated data instantly.
interaction_spec.hover: CTA link underlines on hover with a 200ms transition. Card itself has no hover state -- it should feel like a generous offer, not an interactive target.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All fade and drift animations are disabled. Content appears immediately in its final position.

copy_spec.headline: $3,200/mo
copy_spec.subhead: Average host earnings in your area
dont: Never use urgency language ('Limited spots!', 'Sign up now!')
Never ask a question before giving an answer
Never frame the host's current situation as a problem

elements.html_css:
$3,200/mo

Average host earnings in your area

47 professionals

Active searches

12 weeks

Avg. stay length

4.8 / 5

Host satisfaction

Vetted professionals in your neighborhood are looking for weekday spaces. See what your place could earn -- no sign-up required.

See how your space compares
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts in discovery bounce when the platform demands registration before demonstrating value. Freud identifies this as premature civilizational demand that violates the pleasure principle. This card delivers concrete local earnings data, demand signals, and satisfaction proof without asking for a single piece of information -- protecting the host's pre-civilizational curiosity and making the first contact feel generous rather than extractive.

elements.name: Listing Wizard Progress Card with Auto-Save
elements.description: A dashboard card that shows the host's listing creation progress with a visual completion bar, step-by-step status, and one-click resume or pause controls. This card embodies Freud's insight that listing creation is the peak of instinctual renunciation -- converting private space into public artifact. The auto-save indicator reassures the host that every keystroke is preserved (L4 wizard save-and-resume), the completion bar uses the evidence typographic register to make progress precise (L3 typography), the pause button is frictionless while delete is buried (L4 cautious reversible flows), and the copy treats each step as a dignified exchange rather than a form (L5 dignified surrender). Amber urgency indicators flag incomplete steps without alarm (L3 urgency amber).

visual_spec.layout: Card with 16px padding all around. Top row: listing name + auto-save indicator. Progress bar below. Step checklist with icons. Bottom row: Resume CTA + Pause text link.

color_usage.amber_badge: #c17a28 on #fef3e2 background for steps needing attention

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card renders instantly from cached draft state. Auto-save indicator shows 'Saved' with a small check icon. If no draft exists, card is not shown.
interaction_spec.hover: Resume button shifts to gradient-purple-hover. Pause link underlines. Step rows highlight with a subtle bg-light tint on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Progress bar fill appears at its current width without animation. Check icons appear without fade.

copy_spec.encouragement: Your space is looking great. Two more steps to publish.
dont: Never say 'Your listing is only X% complete' -- frame progress positively
Never use bare imperatives ('Upload photos', 'Set your price')
Never treat the wizard as a form -- each step is a dignified exchange

elements.html_css:
2BR Williamsburg Walk-Up

Saved just now

Your space is looking great. Two more steps to publish.

4 of 6 steps complete

  • Space details
  • Features & amenities
  • Lease style
  • Pricing
  • House rules
  • Photos
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts abandon the listing wizard at the peak of instinctual renunciation because their investment is not visibly preserved and there is no dignified exit. Freud warns that 'if the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders.' This card makes every step's progress visible and saved, provides a frictionless pause that preserves all work, and frames completion as building an achievement rather than filling out a form.

elements.name: Host Dashboard Urgency-First Action Panel
elements.description: The top section of the host dashboard that surfaces action-required items with amber urgency indicators, structured as Freud's civilizational order -- predictable, fixed-position, and anxiety-reducing. This panel implements the L2 urgency-first dashboard hierarchy (action required at top, always), the L3 ritual visual cadence (identical layout every visit), the L3 amber-not-red urgency system (warm attention without alarm), the L4 ritual cadence interaction (stay cycle beats surfaced here), and the L5 civilizational rhythm emotion (sustained calm through predictable structure). The panel never rearranges; the host always knows where to look.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width panel at the top of the dashboard. Contains up to 5 action items in a vertical stack. Each item is a single row: icon + description + deadline + primary action button.
visual_spec.border: none (panel is the top zone; border-bottom 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb) separates it from the status zone below)

color_usage.urgency_badge: #c17a28 text on #fef3e2 background -- warm amber, never red

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Panel renders as the first content on the dashboard. Items appear in urgency order (nearest deadline first). If no actions are pending, the panel shows a calm empty state: 'No pending actions right now. Your listings are active.'
interaction_spec.hover: Individual action items highlight with bg-light tint. Action button underlines on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: No animations. Items render in their final state immediately.

example_items: New proposal from Sarah Chen -- Respond by Feb 21
Date change request from Marcus -- Review
copy_spec.empty_state: Nothing needs your attention right now. Your listings are active and visible to guests.
dont: Never use red badges for routine attention items -- only for errors
Never mix informational items into the action panel
Never change the panel's position on the page across visits

elements.html_css:
Needs your attention

  • New proposal from Sarah Chen

    Respond by Feb 21

  • 2BR Williamsburg listing is 67% complete

    2 steps remaining

  • Date change request from Marcus

    Awaiting your approval
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts waste mental energy scanning a disordered dashboard to find what needs their attention. Freud identifies order as 'a kind of repetition-compulsion by which doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.' This fixed-position panel surfaces urgent items first, every visit, in the same place, using warm amber signals that motivate action without triggering the alarm response that red would produce.

elements.name: Proposal Review Card with Trust-First Architecture
elements.description: A proposal card that resolves the host's stranger-threat anxiety by placing guest trust signals (verification, lease history, review rating, stated purpose) above proposal terms (dates, pricing, duration). Freud's Ch V insight that 'men are not gentle, friendly creatures' informs the architecture: the host's instinctual distrust of the stranger must be resolved before they can rationally evaluate terms. The card implements L1 structured proposals as civilizational compliance signals, L2 stranger-threat reduction through the trust-before-terms scan order, L2 bidirectional protection framing on the action buttons, L3 purple authority on trust badges, L3 evidence register for verification data, L4 optimistic commit on accept, and L5 empowered gatekeeping emotion.

visual_spec.layout: Card divided into three zones: Trust Zone (top, purple-tinted), Terms Zone (middle, white), Action Zone (bottom, white with purple CTA). Max-width 520px.
visual_spec.background: Trust zone: var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252, 250, 255)). Terms zone: var(--bg-white, #ffffff). Action zone: var(--bg-white, #ffffff).

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Trust zone renders first (100ms stagger before terms appear). Verification badge and lease count are the first visible data points. Accept button uses optimistic commit -- instant success state, background server call.
interaction_spec.hover: Accept button shifts to gradient-purple-hover. Counter and Decline links underline on hover. Guest avatar has a subtle purple ring on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: No stagger. All zones render simultaneously. Accept transition is instantaneous.

copy_spec.stated_purpose: Works at Deloitte, needs a weekday space near Midtown for 10 weeks starting March 1.
dont: Never lead with financial terms before trust evidence
Never use urgency language that pressures acceptance
Never label decline as 'Reject' -- use 'Decline'

elements.html_css:

Sarah Chen

Avg rating

$185/night
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts freeze or decline proposals because they encounter financial terms before resolving the fundamental question: is this stranger safe? Freud identifies that 'men are not gentle, friendly creatures' and the host's instinct defaults to distrust when trust evidence is buried. This card places verification status, lease history, rating, and stated purpose above all terms, resolving the stranger-threat question within 3 seconds of opening the proposal.

elements.name: Bidirectional Protection Confirmation Dialog
elements.description: A warm, purple-tinted confirmation surface that replaces standard modal dialogs at every point where the platform enforces a rule (date changes, proposal actions, schedule modifications). It leads with a protection headline and shield icon, shows the bidirectional constraint in parallel statements, and offers a single clear action. Freud's 'first requisite of culture is justice -- the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual' drives the design: the host sees both what they cannot do unilaterally and what the guest also cannot do, making the constraint feel like mutual safety rather than one-sided bureaucracy. Implements L1 justice-not-bureaucracy, L2 bidirectional framing, L3 protection surface visual, L4 bidirectional acknowledgment behavior, and L5 safety emotion.

visual_spec.layout: Centered surface (max-width 440px) over a subtle 10% opacity dark backdrop. Three sections stacked: shield icon + headline, two parallel constraint statements, action buttons.

color_usage.surface_bg: var(--protocol-surface, #F7F2FA) -- warm purple tint, not cold white

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Surface fades in over 200ms ease-out with a subtle backdrop. Focus is trapped inside the dialog. Shield icon and headline are announced first to screen readers.
interaction_spec.hover: Primary button darkens slightly. Secondary button background tints to bg-light on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Surface appears immediately without fade. Backdrop appears without transition.

copy_spec.headline: Both parties are protected
copy_spec.statement_1: Sarah cannot change your agreed schedule without your approval.
copy_spec.statement_2: You also cannot change the schedule without Sarah's agreement.
copy_spec.summary: This keeps things fair for both of you.
dont: Never lead with the restriction ('Date changes require mutual approval')
Never use legal language ('Per the lease agreement...')
Never use punitive framing ('Failure to respond will result in...')
Never use red for the secondary action unless it is genuinely destructive

elements.html_css:
Both parties are protected

Sarah cannot change your agreed schedule without your approval.

You also cannot change the schedule without Sarah's agreement.

This keeps things fair for both of you.
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts experience platform rules as one-sided bureaucratic constraints, developing what Freud calls 'antagonism against civilization' that accumulates toward exit at retention. Standard confirmation dialogs feel like legal notices. This protection dialog leads with a shield icon and 'Both parties are protected' headline, presents reciprocal constraints in visual parallel, and transforms the host's experience from 'I am being controlled' to 'I am being protected.'

elements.name: Stay Cycle Ritual Card
elements.description: A per-stay card within the Stays Manager that tracks the three-beat ritual cadence: arrival confirmation, cleaning photo submission, and micro-review. Freud identifies 'order as a kind of repetition-compulsion by which doubt and hesitation shall be avoided' -- this card is that order made concrete. It uses the exact same layout for every stay cycle so the host knows where to find each piece of information without searching. The cleaning photo thumbnail grid (2x2) provides instant visual evidence that the space was respected. The card implements L1 repetitive rituals for anxiety containment, L2 ritual confirmation cadence (three signals at predictable intervals), L3 ritual visual cadence (fixed layout never rearranges), L3 warm containment, L4 three-beat interaction pattern, and L5 civilizational rhythm emotion (sustained calm through predictability).

visual_spec.layout: Card with fixed internal grid: Top row (guest avatar + dates + status badge), middle section (2x2 cleaning photo grid), bottom row (micro-review prompt or summary). Max-width 480px. Layout identical for every stay.

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card renders from cached stay data. Status badge updates within 1 second of guest confirmation (arrival or cleaning). Photo thumbnails populate progressively as each photo uploads. No loading spinners.
interaction_spec.hover: Photo thumbnails scale up slightly (1.02x) with a subtle shadow on hover, indicating they can be tapped to enlarge. Review prompt underlines on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Photo thumbnails appear without scale animation. Status badge updates without slide transition.

copy_spec.cleaning_pending: Cleaning photos pending -- we have reminded Sarah
copy_spec.all_clear: All clear. Your space is in good hands.
dont: Never over-celebrate routine compliance ('Amazing! Photos submitted!')
Never alarm on delayed rituals ('WARNING: Photos not received!')
Never change the card layout between stays

elements.html_css:
SC

Stay 8 of 10

Feb 17 -- Feb 20 · Sarah Chen

Cleaning Submitted
Arrival confirmed
Cleaning photos
Review

Cleaning photos submitted. Your space looks great.
elements.problem_it_solves: During the active lease, hosts experience recurring anxiety about whether the stranger in their space is respecting the arrangement. Information voids between stays fill with worry. Freud's order principle -- 'repetition-compulsion by which doubt and hesitation shall be avoided' -- prescribes predictable rituals. This card provides three structured beats (arrival, cleaning, review) in an identical layout every cycle, giving the host regular evidence that the civilizational contract is holding.

elements.name: Hosting Summary and Retention Continuation Card
elements.description: A celebration card that appears 24 hours after the final stay of a lease, presenting the host's cumulative hosting record before offering a one-action continuation path. Freud's 'narcissism of minor differences' predicts that the host's retrospective assessment will anchor on small grievances unless counteracted by visible cumulative evidence. This card implements L1 host identity as civilizational binding (cumulative narrative raises exit cost), L2 cumulative investment narrative (total earnings, stays, ratings as a scannable summary), L3 evidence display at hero scale (36px earnings in brand purple), L3 evidence typographic register, L4 one-action continuation (re-listing as continuation, not restart), and L5 retrospective worth emotion (accomplishment as the target feeling). The 'Continue Hosting' CTA reactivates the existing listing in one tap -- no wizard, no rebuild.

visual_spec.layout: Card with generous padding. Hero earnings figure at top. Three supporting metrics in a horizontal row. Hosting timeline bar. Continue Hosting CTA. Max-width 520px.

color_usage.hero_earnings: var(--primary-purple, #31135D) -- largest number on the card, brand authority
color_usage.timeline_fill: var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109, 49, 194)) at varying opacity per lease

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card appears on the dashboard 24 hours after the final stay. Metrics enter with a staggered fade-in: hero earnings first, then supporting metrics 100ms apart, then timeline, then CTA. Continue Hosting uses optimistic commit -- listing reactivates instantly.
interaction_spec.hover: CTA button shifts to gradient-purple-hover. Secondary link underlines on hover. Timeline segments show tooltip with lease details on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All metrics appear simultaneously. No stagger or fade animation. CTA appears in final state.

copy_spec.earnings_label: Total earned since you started hosting
dont: Never present re-listing as a new decision ('Ready to host again?')
Never surface negative data in the retention summary
Never introduce new demands at the retention moment ('Update your photos first')
Never use urgency language ('Don't lose your hosting streak!')

elements.html_css:
Your 3rd lease is complete.

$12,400

Total earned since you started hosting

28 stays

Successful

4.8

Avg rating

14 mo

Hosting tenure

Your hosting journey across 3 leases
elements.problem_it_solves: At retention, hosts perform a retrospective cost-benefit analysis where Freud's 'narcissism of minor differences' anchors on small grievances rather than cumulative benefits. Without a visible counter-narrative, the host remembers the one bad week instead of the $12,400 earned. This card presents cumulative evidence at hero scale before any re-listing prompt, frames continuation as a one-tap action (not a restart), and positions the host's record as an achievement worth preserving -- counteracting the natural drift toward exit.
